Subject: Nature paper about robot adaptation & damage recovery
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=517809752
From: Jean-Baptiste Mouret <jeanbaptiste.mouret@...>

Hi all,

You are probably aware that our last paper was on the cover of Nat=
ure last week (Antoine Cully, Jeff Clune, Danesh Tarapore, and Jean-Baptist=
e Mouret, 2015). We are of course very proud of this and we would be happy =
to answer all your questions about this paper. Perhaps the quickest way to =
gain a high-level overview is via the following short video summary: https:=
//www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DT-c17RKh3uE

The paper is here: http://www.natu=
re.com/nature/journal/v521/n7553/full/nature14422.html (be careful that all=
 the technical details are in the supplementary file, see at the end of the=
 online version). For those who do not have access to Nature, someone has p=
ut a PDF here: http://sciences.blogs.liberation.fr/files/robot-adaptativ-is=
ir.pdf , and the supplementary can be found at the end of the pre-submissio=
n version: http://www.isir.upmc.fr/files/2015ACLI3468.pdf ). There is a nic=
e commentary by Chris Adami in the same issue of Nature: http://sciences.bl=
ogs.liberation.fr/files/robot-adaptativ-isir.pdf

Besides the application t=
o robotics, I think this paper is interesting for our community for several=
 reasons:

- It relies on MAP-Elites to generate a wide diversity of high-p=
erforming solutions. MAP-Elites is a novel, niche-based evolutionary algori=
thm that, in spite of its simplicity, can be seen as a novel abstraction of=
 evolution: each cell of the grid in the feature space is a niche that can =
be invaded by the best individuals of the other niches. You can learn more =
about this algorithm in our recent arxiv draft (http://arxiv.org/abs/1504.0=
4909 , Mouret and Clune, 2015). Because MAP-Elites is focused on creativity=
 and diversity instead of pure optimization, it shares many concepts with N=
ovelty Search (NS), NS with local competition, behavioral diversity, etc. b=
ut also introduces new concepts, like the fact that there is no fixed-size =
population like in traditional evolutionary algorithms.

- While we used si=
mple, open-loop controllers, the exact same technique can be used with your=
 favorite encoding to evolve neural networks (HyperNEAT, SUPG, etc.). Actua=
lly, we have already obtained nice results with SUPG, on the real robot! (w=
e have a report about this in preparation and we will have a talk in the EP=
S workshop at ECAL this summer).

- One the main originality of this paper =
is that it does not attempt to directly evolve solutions on the robot (as m=
any did). Instead, we combine the best of evolution in simulation, with the=
 best of reinforcement learning (direct policy search). In more concrete te=
rms, our approach divides the process into two steps: an exploration phase =
with an evolutionary algorithm, in simulation (this allows us to use evolut=
ion for what it shines: using a lot of evaluations to be creative), and an =
adaptation phase based on Bayesian Optimization (which is a very data-effic=
ient learning/optimization algorithm). We could also see the second step as=
 surrogate-based evolution, with a surrogate based on the simulation.

- Ov=
erall, we are interested to know what you think

Best regards,
=97 Jean-Bap=
tiste Mouret
http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/~mouret/
